Sakura is followed by one of the people who had seen her
135332212112121112121.content:
The next morning, Sakura awoke to find that she was having difficulty breathing. An immense weight was keeping her from taking in enough air.

She opened her eyes to see Koji, still slumbering, but on top of her human body!

'What?' Sakura thought, her body had returned to normal and she was wearing the fur suit again.

'The suit must still have some bugs in it...' the pink haired teenager concluded. 'I better get back to Lady Tsunade and fix it before the other kids see me.'

Stealthily, Sakura slid her body from under Koji and began to sneak out of Chira's room.

Even in her baggy raiment, Sakura was able to leave the cave without attracting attention.

"I just hope Ichikuma-san doesn't think I'm deserting him." Sakura whispered to herself as she came to the edge of Safe Home.

The Kunoichi then came out through the hidden entrance and used the necklace to contact Tsunade. Now all she had to do now was wait.

Little did she realize that two people had seen her leave Safe Home.

One was a brooding young bear, the other a seasoned hunter with a vendetta against Ichikuma...
135332212112121112121.title: You gotta hate faulty Bear suits...

choices: She returns to the Safe Home, no one is angry at her absence.
1353322121121211121211.content:
"Meet at the cave at the foot of the mountain due south of your position. It will look like a large bear's maw."

Those were Sakura's orders, and she was left to wander through the violent blizzard with only an over-sized bear suit and a thin layer of clothing. Navigating through the blinding snow was somewhat difficult, she could hardly see ten feet in front of her. The wind ripped at the brown fur of the suit but it was still able to make her completely warm.

At last, after wandering for what seemed like hours, a large white mountain took up the entirety of Sakura's limited field of vision. She peaked through the bear suit's eye holes to try to find the bear shaped entrance Lady Tsunade spoke of.

A jutting gray snout with icicles for teeth caught her eye. "Bingo!"

Trudging through the waist deep snow mounds, Sakura finally made it to the mouth of the cave. Unfortunately, there was no sign of Lady Tsunade, or anyone for that matter. The cave seemed completely abandoned though once occupied. Piles of ruffed straw and feathers were in the corner, most likely makeshift beds. There were also bones scattered all around the floor.

Reaching down with a floppy bear hand, Sakura picked up a nearby skull to examine it. She gulped, it was a human skull.

"Sakura!" Shouted a voice from behind her.

"GAAAH!" Shrieked the genin, dropping the skull and falling to the floor. The speaker was a humanoid figure wrapped in layers of coats, scarfs, blankets, and all manner and assortments of warm clothing. It tore off the scarfs and goggles surrounding its face.

"L-Lady Tsunade! You scared me half to death!" The pink haired ninja took several deep breathes as the Hokage chuckled and continued to remove several layers of clothing.

"My apologizes Sakura, I thought you'd be more on guard considering where you are..."

"Where I am...What do you mean my Lady?"

Tsunade sighed and shook her head, she was having trouble with a zipper on one of her coats. "Oh, it doesn't matter. So tell me, the bear suit is giving you trouble?"

Sakura lifted her heads to show the sagging material of the costume.

"I see...Well turn around, I'll have a look at the data."

Sakura obliged and waited patiently as Tsunade took off her gloves with her teeth. With two free hands, Tsunade poked a cold metal panel embedded in the suit directly at the center of Sakura's back. She heard several beeps followed by a confused huff from the Hokage.

"What is it, Lady Tsunade? Has something malfunctioned?"

"That's just it. According to the data, absolutely nothing is wrong with the suit. Everything is running perfectly...Here, let me see what happens when I try to eject you from it. Normally it will take twenty four hours but..."

Another beep sound was heard and the suit sprung to life, opening up like a bag down the center of the stomach. It plopped to the floor around Sakura's ankles, while she shivered in place. Standing in her usual regiment in a freezing cold cave made her wish the suit hadn't been removed.

"Now that's odd...Something is definitely wrong with the suit Sakura." Said Tsunade as she gathered up its remains. "Looks like we should have gone to the tech guys to begin with. Oh well."

With teeth chattering, Sakura nodded. "C-c-can I b-b-borrow a c-c-c-coat Lady Tsu-u-u-unade? I'm f-f-f-freezing-"

The moment the memory of being in a warm bear body entered her head was the moment something clicked in her body. The little panel on the bear suit lit up in Tsunade's hands and Sakura suddenly began to grow!

"Sakura! You're..."

But Sakura had already noticed. Her pink hair had begun to spread all over her body, covering her plumping form. The familiar sensation of bones realigning themselves and snapping into place made her wince in pain. For some reason she was become a polar bear with the suit on!

"L-Lady Tsunade..." Whimpered Sakura as her mouth pushed out into a snout. "What's happening!?"

Sakura' entire form had grown from a petite young woman into a nearly full grown bear in a matter of seconds, much faster than the rate of transformation when she had the suit on. Claws and teeth had already taken their place in their respective areas.

"I...Wish I knew, did you do something Sakura? Anything! Think of something? Touch something!?"

"I-I was just remembering how warm it was as a bear and-"

"That's it! Try to think of being a human again! Think of the shape of your old body, picture it in your head!"

Sakura obeyed and closed her eyes thinking about being a human again. The form of it...How weak it felt in comparison of being a massive bear but how comfortable it was at the same time. She felt a sinking feeling run over her. She opened her eyes and saw that she was shrinking, it worked!

As quickly as she transformed into a bear, she returned to her human self. The fur simply was absorbed back into her body and her structure returned to a human's anatomy. Afterward, she felt dizzy and cold again. But at least she was normal. Stepping forward, she slipped and feel into Tsunade's arms.

"Easy does it...This is quite remarkable, you seemed to have completely absorbed the suit's power! Your body must have reacted to the amount of chakra that was lost and took in the suit's power as compensation. The suit's ability has basically been added to your will."

"Wha...What does that mean?"

Tsunade grinned. "It means you get to go back on your mission!"

Sakura groaned. "Oh...boy..."
1353322121121211121211.title: Into the Frozen Maw.

choices: Sakura chooses to explore the city, instead.
13533221211212111212111.content:
The blizzard hadn't exactly died down by the time Tsunade sent Sakura packing back to the Safe Home. The snow was higher than ever and showed no signs of stopping, flecks of the quarter sized pellets clung to Sakura's pink fur. At least when she was the size of a bear, walking through the ocean of snow was considerably less difficult. Still, this mission was already growing tiresome. Thoughts of returning home to her nice warm bed continually taunted the poor girl...

But then Sakura remembered Chira and Koji, even Kusase. Ichikuma had been gracious enough to welcome her into their home, even if humans weren't exactly welcomed. She had to go back, if at least for them.

Sakura squinted to see through the waves of snowflakes that clouded her vision. "Now...Which way was the tree again...?"

Finding ones way around a familiar yet distorted environment was proving quite difficult. And yet there was an almost entire sense of drawing, like Sakura knew exactly where she was going. A sort of beacon in the distance was calling her, guiding her through the blizzard.

Sakura sighed to herself. "I guess I just have to trust it..."

~

Meanwhile, in a cave not too far from where Sakura was. The hunter loomed over a roaring fire, cooking a large piece meat while his hunting dog continued to bark loudly at the cave entrance. He had to block it off with snow, it would be impossible to hunt out in that blizzard meaning he and his companion were forced indoors...For now.

Grinning two gold teeth under a giant beard, the man turned to his dog. "Easy boy, eh? She's 'ut there, huh?"

The dog almost seemed to understand him and barked once in response.

Laughing, the hunter took a big bite out of his lunch. "'On't worry...She can't 'utrun us forev'r. It 'nly takes 'ne to lead us to 'he nest..."

~

In no time at all, Sakura had found the tree and was descending the stairs down into the Safe Home.

The sounds of a city were echoing off the stairway walls as Sakura's stomach growled. She hadn't eaten anything all day so far, it had to be lunchtime by now. That would explain the bustling sounds resonating below.

Indeed, her theory was proven correct. Just like yesterday, the main hall was packed with hundreds of the pink polar bears wandering around and chatting with each other. The smells of fresh fish and beef filled Sakura's nostrils making her drool slightly.

A few younger bears bumped into her and apologized, but she was too busy trying to remember where Ichikuma's home was to notice anything.

"Hmm...Now where did they live again-?"

"Oi! Sakura!" Bellowed a booming voice from behind her. She jumped slightly.

"Ichikuma-san! S-sorry, you scared me..."

Sakura turned to face the great bear, who was grinning. That was a good sign at least, he wasn't angry about her disappearance this morning. Sakura also noticed that the others were nowhere to be seen.

Ichikuma noticed her stares. "Wondering where Chira, Kuji, and Kusase are?"

"Oh! Uh, yes...But Ichikuma-san, I'm sorry for leaving like that this morning there was some difficulty with..." She paused and lowered her voice slightly. "...The suit."

He smiled. "It's no trouble, I figured something must have happened and just told Chira and Kuji you had urgent business on the surface. Both of them missed you terribly this morning though."

"Yeah, I feel awful leaving all of a sudden like that. Where are they now anyway?"

"School, where you should be now as a matter of fact."

Sakura stuttered slightly. "S-school? But-but I graduated already and-"

"Correction." Interrupted Ichikuma. "You graduated from a human school. We keep our young in schools until they're old enough to mate. I can take you there if you wish, but I'll leave it up to you. You're here to learn from us, correct?"

"Y-yes..."

He grinned, showing his large sharp teeth. "Well, wouldn't you think a school is the best place to start? As I said I won't force you to go, you can learn much about us by just walking through the city. What do you say though?"

Sakura thought for a brief minute.
13533221211212111212111.title: The Return Journey.

choices: Sakura gets put in class with Kusase & a friendly blonde she bear called Noi
She gets put in another class.
135332212112121112121111.content:
In the end Sakura decided that going to school would be the best way to learn about the Momoiro.

“I suppose it wouldn’t be too bad,” Sakura said as she followed Ichikuma while they ambled about the Safe Home. ‘After all, I am a shinobi, not to mention Lady Tsunade’s apprentice.’

“I’m glad you decided to go Sakura.” Ichikuma told her as they passed another group of bears. “The school teaches our young cubs to better survive in the world, as well as information about humans. Although some days are less exciting than others, it really is an enjoyable experience. Kusase says it’s the only time he can get peace of mind.”

Sakura’s eyes widened in surprise, Sasuke always seemed so indifferent in the Ninja Academy despite his inherited talent. “Really? He likes going to school?”

“Yes. As a matter of fact, not even Chira or Kuji complain about it.” Just then, Ichikuma stopped before a large rock formation. “Looks like we’re here.”
Sakura looked up to find herself before an imposing cave exit, which looked like a roaring bear. The mouth was the opening, with stalagmites and stalactites serving as teeth. The stony figures were so huge, they dwarfed Ichikuma. At the top of the natural, but realistic figure were the ears, and below them, in just the right place were the eyes, where two windows were. Sakura only stood there in awe.

“Did yo-er, I mean our people make this?” She asked curiously, entranced by the enigmatic school’s exterior. She had corrected herself to keep any listeners from growing suspicious.

The older bear shook his head no. “No, interestingly enough this formation has been here for ages, predating the arrival of our kind in Safe Home. Our ancestors decided that it was sacred, and should only be used for important purposes. No human has ever set foot within, including the rare few who had managed to stumble into Safe Home.” He then turned to Sakura, “You’ll be the first.”

“Are you sure it’s okay? I mean you said it was considered to be sacred.” The kunoichi in bear form asked.

“The moment you came into our household I considered you to be a member of my family, that as well as your current form would make you eligible to enter.” As the rose furred polar bear finished his last syllables, a bell rang out. “Oh, classes have begun! Come on in Sakura and I’ll get you registered.”

“Okay Ichikuma!”
135332212112121112121111.title: Sakura decides to go to "school".

choices: The bell for Sakura's first class rings.
1353322121121211121211111.content:
Following closely behind, Sakura stepped past the imposing teeth of the entrance taking in the sights and sounds of the cave. The wind that blew out of the cave made it sound like she was really stepping into a giant bear's mouth, it roared and howled along the cave walls shaking her very core. Speaking of the walls, they were heavily decorated with cave paintings and skins of various animals. Small torches aligned the wall, giving a deep orange glow that lit the hall.

Then the sounds of children echoed in the distance, they must have been approaching a classroom. Sure enough, the hall widened and the ceiling grew higher until at last Sakura and Ichikuma stood in what appeared to be a auditorium. It was a bowl-like room that collapsed into a massive bear statue made of hard rock in the center.

Young bears of various shades of pink and sizes sat around on the seats that traversed down the bowl floor. Several of them stopped from their prattle and looked at the newcomer with bits of food in their mouths. It was apparently cafeteria time.

A strong looking purple shaded male bear that had a fur pattern that made it appear he was almost wearing glasses walked up the steps to greet the two. He spoke in an educated and quirky voice, taking care to pronounce every word spoken properly.

"Greetings Lord Ichikuma. What do we owe the great pleasure of your presence gracing our fine establishment? There's nothing wrong, is there?"

"Quite the contrary Speaker Atama, I come bringing you a new student. She was a little...lost this morning and couldn't arrive during the start of your sessions. Sakura, this is Speaker Atama. He will be your teacher."

Sakura did a slight bow. "How do you do?"

Atama gawked slightly. "My word. Such odd mannerisms, what part of the Safe Home do you come from my dear?"

Ichikuma butted in. "Sorry, I should have mentioned. She's from the surface and knows little of the...'mannerisms' of the Momoiro. However, I have taken her in as one of my family. I'd wish you treat as one."

"Yes, yes, of course Lord Ichikuma! I was merely curious, the last surfacer I taught nearly got into a brawl with me over study habits. We had to expel him unfortunately."

"Surfacer? You had to expel him?" Asked Sakura, detecting a hint of annoyance in his voice.

Atama quickly correctly. "Oh, no no! Please dear girl, don't take me as prejudice! He was one of my favorite students, he just didn't have a knack for the way of the Momoiro and returned to the surface..."

"Wow, learning is taken really seriously then?"

"Indeed. Now Lord Ichikuma, I can take you to my office and we can sort out the proper paperwork."

Atama then turned to Sakura. "Your name was Sakura, correct? I believe I saw Kusase sitting around here somewhere if you wish to sit with someone familiar...Ahh! There he is!"

He pointed to a bench not that far from where they were standing. Kusase had apparently noticed they spotted him and groaned, slumping down low to discourage her. Sakura frowned slightly.

"Go ahead Sakura." Nudged Ichikuma. "I need to go with Speaker Atama and register you."

"Alright. Thank you, Ichikuma."

~

The crowds of young bears made Sakura feel a little out of her element. She was used to quiet study lessons with an occasional prank done by Naruto. This group was large and loud, there had to be easily a thousand bears in the hall.

As Sakura pushed her way through a particularly rowdy group of bears, she found a place next to Kusase. He just huffed at her arrival.

Sakura smiled and tried to introduce a conversation. "This place is a mad house! And your uncle says this is the only place you get some peace of mind?"

He grunted. Sakura tried again.

"You don't talk much, do you? Don't like conversation?"

"No. Just don't like you." He replied, giving her a suspicious look.

Sakura made a disappointed face. "Where have I heard that one before..."

But before Kusase could give his own witty retort, an almost unbearable shrilly voice cried out in the distance. "Kusaseeeeeeeeeeeee!"

What appeared to be a big yellow boulder slammed into Kusase's back, though he was surprisingly able to hold his ground against the weight of whatever landed on him. Sakura was surprised to discover it was a blond female bear with a long yellow ponytail.

"...The last person I wanted to see right now." Muttered Kusase.

The blond bear giggled. "Don't say that! I know you're crazy for me Kusase!"

"More like I'd have to be crazy to like you..."

The bear huffed. "Fine! Play hard to get!"

"Um, excuse me?" Interrupted Sakura.

The bear looked up, apparently not even noticing Sakura had been sitting there the entire time. "Oh, hi! You're the newcomer right! Sorry! I didn't mean to interrupt your conversation! I just haven't seen my dear Kusase since yesterday!"

"I'm not your dear Kus-" Kusase tried to get out.

"Anyway!" The bear released Kusase and turned her attention to Sakura. "Pleased to meet you! I'm Noi! Who are you?"

"Noi, huh? Small world...Sorry, my name's Sakura. Nice to meet you too." Sakura smirked. She was just like Ino in every way.

"Sakura, huh? Sounds a little familiar somehow...Whatever, though. What part of the city are you from Sakura?"

"She's from the surface." Said Kusase, in an uncaring tone. He was trying to get Noi to get into conversation with Sakura so he could slip away.

"The surface, huh? No wonder you're a newcomer! What's it like up there? I hear it's hard to live up there." Kusase slowly inched away from Noi.

"Oh, it's not too bad. Still this city is amazing. I never thought something like this would exist down here." Kusase got real low.

"You're telling me! Know what we should go shopping together after classes! I can show you around." Kusase climbed under the bench without getting noticed.

"I'd like that. How long are classes supposed to go away?" Kusase was now home free.

"Oh, well it's lunch now so only for another three hours and...Hey! Where did Kusase go?"

135332212221.content:
Within the ninja world there are many tales and many different kinds of shinobi. Some ninja were sages with their own summoning creatures and jutsu.

There were summoning creatures of renown, such as the toads of Mount Myoboku, the great serpents of the Ryuchi Cave, and the slugs of Shikkotsu Forest. These, along with several others were partnered with sages and regular shinobi, helping to mold and shape the world with their wisdom.

However, some summoning creature were different than others and were less known of. One of which were the bear shinobi. The bears lived in the Land of Bears, long forgotten and in deep hibernation since shortly after the time of the Sage of the Six Paths.

The Bears were known for their protective nature and great strength, among many other traits. They had served ninjas well in their time, but eventually the sage that knew of their secrets and made contract with them passed, as did public knowledge of their society. The bears themselves soon entered a deep hibernation and the scroll that allowed the making of contracts was lost to mankind…

However, there were those who slowly and gradually awoke many centuries later. This was during a time they were largely forgotten, just as the world was recovering from the latest ninja war.

As a few of them rose from their slumber, they began to make their way past the deep forest and began to roam, wondering what had become of the ninja world.
135332212221.title: Bears of the Ninja World

1353322122212.content:
To say life was simpler after the Great War would be a complete lie. The truth was universal peace was always hard to achieve, though there was at least no outright hostility between the nations. Still, there was at least some progress. For example, a year ago Hinata would have never been on a patrol around Konoha borders with a Sand and Mist ninja as her allies.

Yet there she was, jumping from tree to tree with a broody-looking Mist kunoichi named Spades and a tall dark fellow from the Sands with a massive hammer by the name of Raz. Both were genin under her command.

Raz stopped suddenly, being the one on point. Hinata and Spades also came to a halt at the tree he was perched on.

“More tilled forests,” Raz observed. “They seem to be coming from the south.”

“G-Good eye,” replied Hinata as she took a moment to use her Byakugan to survey the land. As before, there was nothing but giant tracks along the path of fallen trees. “Still nothing, n-no sign of the cause.”

“We couldn’t do anything if we did find them,” sighed Spades as she leaned on her trademark shovel. “We’re just genin.”

“Don’t say that,” Raz slapped Spades on the shoulder in an attempt to lighten her mood. “The Commander was in the final battle of the war. Between you, me, and her, we can handle anything.”

“I doubt it.”

“I-I’m right here, you know,” muttered Hinata. Since the Great War and while acting squad leader, she had been tried to be more vocal.

“Well, it’s true, isn’t it?” asked Raz. “You were there when everything went down with Naruto and Sasuke. In the final push.”

“There were a lot of people there…,” the idea of being some sort of war hero didn’t exactly sit well with the Hyuga heiress. “What matters is the mission. S-Stay focused.”

“It’s just a patrol mission,” Spades gloomily stated. “Nothing exciting ever happens.”

“Hey, I can hope. Can’t I?” Raz smiled widely. Hinata could tell the large ninja was eager to prove himself.

“Enough,” Hinata was losing control over her troops this early on in the mission. That was a bad sign. It was time for a new tactic to keep them focused on the task at hand. “L-Let’s split up. Follow the tracks and report back on a-any sign of trouble.”

The genin respectfully bowed and took off in separate directions.

Hinata sighed a breath of relief, still not used to the idea of commanding soldiers. So far, in comparison to her last few missions, this one had gone relatively smoothly. But she couldn’t rejoice yet. Everyone in the village was doing their part to rebuild and grow stronger after so many resources had been spent in the war. Hinata would do her part as well. She would grow stronger, both in the self and as a community with Konoha. Even if it meant doing what some might consider a trivial task as investigate the strange deforestation in the south.

After collecting herself for a moment, Hinata immediately sprung into actions and followed the path of broken timber down to a large lake next to the mountains. Most of the outback was unsettled by anyone, with only empty highways as the single means of civilization. This meant her travel through the woods was pleasantly quiet as she approached the lakeside.

She stopped at another group of large tracks, each the size of a small house. This was the first time she had gotten to look at them up close.

“Not a wolf or a tiger,” as she might have initially thought. “There are large p-pads. More like bobcat. O-Or a—”

SPLASH

Hinata sprung into a defensive stance, as something rippled in the water right in front of her. The echo was loud enough that the cause had to be something large, which only disturbed her; something as big as a small car had gotten the jump on her. When she looked up, she saw exactly what it was.

“A-A bear?”

A full-grown bear would be too generous to label this creature. Judging by its proportions, it was a simple cub. However, this “cub” was easily three times as large as she was. Worse, it looked to be in pain.

Hinata’s motherly instincts took over as the animal limped towards her, fur soaked from the lake. “O-Oh, my. Hold still! Don’t move!”

The creature must have interpreted her peaceful intent for it quietly slumped up to the beach and collapsed on its side. As Hinata approached the mammoth sized baby bear she saw exactly what was troubling it. A pike-sized wooden splinter had impaled it through its hind leg.

Though she had limited medical training, Hinata sprung into actions. She first attempted to soothe the cub with gentle coos as she firmly grasped the handle of the spear. Using chakra infused fingertips, she gently pressed on various pressure points along the wound that would numb the pain of the removal process. When all preparations were made, she thrust the splint out in one quick pull before closing the injury as best as she could with tape.

“T-There,” she whispered, patting the bandaged leg of her handiwork. “That should s-stabilize you long enough to heal naturally.”

All the while, the cub had not made a single peep through Hinata’s work. Yet, when there was the caw of a flock of birds in the air, it turned and let out a loud cry.

Hinata had a bad feeling in her stomach as the earth began to shake. Something larger than the cub was approaching and she didn’t have time to run from it. Crashing through the brook came the largest bear she had ever seen. It was the size of a summoned beast, like Naruto’s toads or Lady Tsunade’s slugs. Worst of all, it look very angry.

The great brown bear came to a halt right at its kin and let out a roar that sent a flurry of winds nearly knocking her off her feet. But she stood her ground, hoping that the help she had granted the cub would be a peace offering. It didn’t take a genius to realize that this was clearly the mother bear and she was not happy to see her child in such a state.

“Commander Hinata!” called out a voice.

Hinata’s eyes shot over to Raz and Spades, who were coming in to aid her. They were going to get themselves killed if the big bear focused on them instead.

“STAY THERE!” she ordered, surprisingly them both by the volume of her voice.

Thankfully, the giant bear paid her squad no mind. It sniffed the cub, checking to see if it was alright. When the smaller bear licked the gigantic snout of the mother, the big bear gave Hinata her full attention. It appeared to be sizing her up with its bowling ball sized pupils. It drew in closer and wrapped its blanket-like tongue around Hinata.

“Ugh!” Hinata cried, trying not to breath in the bear’s horrible breathe.

Once Hinata was a wet, dripping mess, the bear snatched the cub up with its teeth by the collar and took off in the direction it had come from. Hinata’s teammates cautiously approached their commander, who was covered head to toe with saliva.

“Nice one, commander,” said Raz as he punched Hinata in the shoulder, only to wipe his hands off on his sleeve from the bear spittle.

“Those were very large bears,” observed Spades, still in shock at what she had just witnessed.

“Y-Yes,” muttered Hinata as she attempted to clean herself off. “W-Well, at least we know what caused the damage to the local forest.”
1353322122212.title: Close Bear Encounters

choices: Their mission leads them to an old temple.
The team gets hunted by an unseen force.
13533221222121.content:
“The damage is spreading into the farmlands in the south and beyond,” muttered the small elder toad Fukasaku. “The Honorable Geezer has expressed concern that the bears may soon spread into the realms of the other summonable beasts.”

Kakashi sat at his desk, in full Hokage attire, miring over the situation. Hinata shifted uncomfortably in place, not expecting her report on the discovered cause of the forest destruction to be so muddled in ninja politics. A few high ranking representations were in the office with her, not including Naruto and his frog friend. There were a few officials Hinata did not recognize from the neighboring villages, no doubt here to petition Konoha to act on the bear problem.

“Tell me again,” said Kakashi after giving the matter a long thought. “Hinata, the bears took off after simply…Licking you?”

“O-Once I had healed the cub, yes.”

“You should have let the beast die,” said one lord from a trading village along the south river. “Those mongrels have been terrible for business, scaring away our merchants, our livelihood.”

“I reckon the bears have as much right to exist as you or me,” said Fukasaku from Naruto’s shoulder.

“But you were the one just complaining about the damage they were causing!”

“I only meant they needed to be stopped, you dang whipper snapper!” croaked the old toad. “Butchering them would be sacrilege given the history of these noble beasts.”

“I’ve never heard of bear summons before,” said Naruto.

“That’s because they haven’t revealed themselves for centuries,” continued his frog companion. “They disappeared long ago before I can even remember. They were mere stories of legend in my youth, if you can believe it. Their return is a rare occurrence and should be welcomed…Provided they don’t destroy half of Konoha.”

“The problem is the delicate peace they’d be compromising if they’re allowed to continue,” continued Kakashi. “Lord Fukasaku, you wanted me to have Hinata join us. What was your reason?”

“Yes,” said the frog as he motioned for Naruto to bring him closer to the Hyuga. Hinata gulped slightly as the old toad jumped onto her shoulder and surveyed her at an uncomfortably close angle. “Young lady, you said the bear licked you, correct?”

“Y-Yes…”

“Well, that solves our problem. You’ve been marked.”

Hinata didn’t like the sound of that. “W-What does that mean?”

“I’ve heard of this,” said Kakashi as he put his hand to his masked chin. “In the days before man were respected as masters of jutsu, the beasts would not simply bow to them under contract. They chose their pupils through their own trials. Your kind heart must have impressed one of them.”

“Correct,” nodded Fukasaku. “I suspect they’ll speak to no one but this girl.”

“Then it’s settled. Hinata, you will gather up your team and speak with these mythical bears as an ambassador, if they truly have accepted you.”

“And if they haven’t?” asked Naruto. “Master Kakashi, it’s dangerous to send them in alone like that. I mean, I saw those tracks. Those bears are huuuuge!”

“Then go with them if you’re so worried,” Kakashi shrugged, putting his hands behind his head. “As far as I’m concerned, you have free reign, Naruto, given that any mission we’d send you on would be overkill at this point. You’re more famous than I am.”

Naruto grunted and rubbed his nose. Since the end of the War, there was not a person alive who didn’t know his name. Hinata was glad he’d be coming along, given that they hadn’t had much time to talk since after the battle.

"Just so we’re clear, Naruto.” Kakashi sat up straight and stopped using his carefree tone. “This is a diplomatic mission and Hinata is your squad leader. You will obey her commands and not do ANYTHING to compromise our chance at a peaceful resolution. Am I clear?”

“Yes, Lord Hokage.”

“Good. Dismissed.”

~

The afternoon was busy with a slight chill in the air suggesting the coming autumn. Hinata bundled up with her usual lavender hoodie as she walked with Naruto outside the Hokage tower. A peaceful pass through the park with her boyfriend was exactly what she needed after a long day in the forest. Well, that and a shower after being licked by a mountain sized bear.

“T-Thanks for coming along, Naruto.”

“Hey, I know a thing or two about being the only one to calm a bunch of giant monsters,” chuckled the blond troublemaker. “I don’t want to see you get hurt out there.”

Hinata smiled and clasped her crush’s hand. It had taken a long time to work up her courage, but it was completely worth the embarrassment of admitting her feelings. Naruto felt the same way giving her fingers a slight squeeze as they moved along. It was ironic that their budding romance had begun in a season of decay. But at least they would have this mission to themselves.

“Commander!”

Spoke too soon.

Hinata quickly released Naruto’s hand and looked up to see her subordinates Raz and Spades jumping down from the nearby building.

“And Naruto! Wow,” said Raz, somewhat star struck. “Can I get your autograph?”

“Well…” Naruto sheepishly grinned.

But Hinata wasn’t about to let them be distracted. Not while there was a mission to do. “Lord Kakashi has o-ordered us to serve as ambassadors to this bear tribe.”

“Bear sloth,” corrected Spades.

“R-Right,” continued Hinata. “We need to communicate with the sloth and come to good terms with them, h-however long it takes. Naruto will be escorting us. W-We are not to attack the bears under any circumstances for this is a peacekeeping mission. Take this seriously.”

Raz nodded and straightened up. “Yes, ma’am.”

“We leave tomorrow at dawn. A-Are there any questions?”

“No ma’am,” both ninjas saluted.

“G-Good, dismissed.”
13533221222121.title: Exposition to an Expedition

choices: Hinata decides the gang should split up. Oddly, the bear follows her.
Hinata follows Spades's advice and traps the bear.
135332212221212.content:
Hinata and her team began their travel towards the Land of Bears, the trip taking several days. Hinata was glad to spend the time with Naruto and getting to know her charges better. While Raz and Spades were talented genin, they were also quite new to being a ninja.

Hinata was glad to spend a few moments of peace with them and Naruto.

As they entered the dense forest area of the Land of Bears, passing Hoshigakure. The foursome made camp deep within the woods, with them sitting in front of a campfire. Naruto was busily slurping down as much ramen as he could.

With admiration, Raz started to quiz the hero of the Great Ninja War.

“So, is it true you fought alongside lord Gaara?”

“Yeah, I even beat him once before he was Kazekage. He’s one of my best friends, though.”

“Wow, that’s pretty awesome. I knew he spoke highly of you, but I never knew you two were personally acquainted.”

“Yeah, well, awesome ninja gotta stick together.” Naruto smiled pridefully, not noticing Spades’s annoyed expression. “Maybe one day you guys will be able to surpass me.”

“To do that all we have to do is pass the Chunin exam.”

Naruto was silenced after that. Even after the Great Ninja War he STILL hadn’t passed the Chunin exam. He decided it would be best not to broach the subject further, while Hinata found more merit in trying to change the topic.

“We may as well rest now. We’ll be near our destination tomorrow and we need to be ready to talk with the bears.”

“Are you sure it’ll be safe, Master Hinata?” Raz asked. “I mean, they might try to eat us.”

“Bears don’t eat people,” Spade said. “They attack if their territory is invaded or their cubs are in danger, but not to eat humans. Since we are invading their area, we might be in for some danger.”

“We’ll be ready to face it after a good night’s sleep. I’ll keep watch, you two rest.”

“Yes, Master Hinata.” Spades went into her tent after that, while Raz did the same with his own.

Still outside, Hinata saw Naruto fidgeting with his new arm. Apparently, it was still troubling him.

“Are you okay?”

“Yeah, I’m gonna be fine. I can still do jutsu and all, it’s just harder to use than my old one. Just makes me think of everything we lost in the war.”

“You sacrificed a lot for us.”

“Not as much as others,” Naruto said wistfully. Hinata recalled the lost ninja, many from various villages and others close to her heart. Neji in particular came to her mind.

Her cousin, the genius of the Hyuga clan and one of the reasons Hinata desired to be stronger, was lost forever. Hinata only had her memory of him and a desire to be worthy to someday lead the Hyuga clan.

“Yes, but those sacrifices have just made us stronger. We have to look at the future so those sacrifices mean something.”

“Yeah, you’re right. Anyway, do you want me to keep you company on your watch Hinata?”

“Sure. I wouldn’t mind.”

Sitting side by side, the two kept watch.

Hours passed and Hinata was certain the group was fine. Naruto took over and the shifts went by until morning. As the group began to move ahead, they noticed that there was a malevolent presence.

“Everyone, we have company.”

“We do?” Raz asked as he came from his tent, reaching for his hammer.

“Yes. I think it might be one of our bears.” Hinata had briefly activated her Byakugan in order to look at the source of the disturbance. True enough, it was a bear that was lumbering nearby. It was smaller than even the cubs that she had encountered before. Still, she didn’t want to take any risks. “Naruto, can you send out a shadow clone to investigate?”

“On it!” Naruto performed the necessary hand signs and summoned a shadow clone. His duplicate advanced slowly to check out the situation.

It took a few moments and by then Hinata noticed he seemed to sigh.

“Naruto, what’s wrong?”

“Uh, the bear isn’t from the sloth we’re looking for. In fact, I think its just a wild bear.”

“Then why’re you acting so worried?” Spades asked.

“Well, my shadow clone tried talking to it, but it wasn’t paying attention. I kinda tried to poke it and it attacked my clone.”

“You mean you provoked it?” Spades asked.

Just then the bear came running out from the woods after them. The four picked up their things and ran off.

“I didn’t do it on purpose!” Naruto yelled back.

“Wait, can’t we just take the bear down? We’re ninja for crying out loud!” Raz said.

“No, we can’t risk offending the sloth we’re looking for,” Hinata explained. “If they look over the wild bears then this might be seen as an act of aggression.”

“But what if we just trap it? No harming involved.” Spades looked at the bear. It couldn’t keep up, but they likely couldn’t outrun it if they stayed in a group.

Hinata considered the options and came up with a solution.
135332212221212.title: The team gets hunted by an unseen force.

choices: Hinata takes a vial of the water back to her teammates.
Hinata accidentally gets her hand wet with the water...
1353322122212121.content:
“Split up,” ordered Hinata. “T-Try to lose it in the forest and do not engage it under any circumstances!”

“Roger,” the three other ninja called out as they jumped off into the trees in separate directions.

The rampaging bear gave a brief look of confusion before singling out on the only remaining ninja in the clearing, Hinata herself. The Hyuga would have kicked herself for loitering around if she had the time, but it was all she could do to jump out of the bear’s may. She narrowly missed being mauled by its claws as she climbed up the branch of a nearby tree.

“Remind me to smack Naruto later…”

The bear continued to follow her around as she leapt through the forest, bashing into the trees in an attempt to bring her down. Naruto must have really made it angry. Yet, for all its rage, it never once damaged the forest. Every tree it hit remained intact as Hinata led it deeper into the woods.

~

Minutes of this dangerous game of whack-a-mole passed until Hinata found that there were no more trees to hide atop on.

Thankfully, the forest had come to a stop right in front of a mountain, and at the foot of that mountain was a large cave. Hinata wasted no time scrambling inside before the bear came charging inside behind her. Thankfully, with her eyes, Hinata could see perfectly in the dark while the bear relied solely on its sense of smell to find her.

“GRRRORRRR!” it snarled in the blackness, pawing its way through the tunnel.

Hinata quietly crept through the cave, heading deeper in with the plan to lure the bear inside and escape while it got lost looking for her. As she wandered into the darkness, she realized that the cavern was actually getting wider. Eventually she came to what she thought was the very back of the cave. It was a dead end in an almost circular room. At the center was an unusual pool of water, bubbling like it was alive.

“How odd,” she muttered to herself. “A-An underground hot spot?”

She was given little time to ponder it as the bear’s roars echoed along the walls. Hinata swiftly dove behind one of the many nearby stalagmites just as the beast came stumbling into the central chamber.

The bear grumbled confusedly as it pawed at the rocks along the ground, trying to catch Hinata’s scent. The ninja was suddenly very grateful she had found the strange bubbling pool of water. The sound prevented the bear from hearing her and it distracted the creature entirely. In fact, the bear seemed to lose all interest in even chasing Hinata, instead it waddled up to the edge of the underground pond.

Hinata peaked her head out from the rocks and quietly watched as the bear stared deep into the pool, despite it being too dark to see. It began to yammer to itself before dipping its head into the waters.

“Oh, my…” Hinata whispered to herself as she watched the bear begin to grow.

The water appeared to have a bizarre effect on the bear as it started to swell to gigantic proportions. It wasn’t long before the bear was nearly as large as the chamber itself. Only then did it stop drinking, looking far more content and peaceful. It seemed to have forgotten about Hinata entirely, and for good reason. It was now bigger than that cub she had encountered previously in the woods.

Hinata continued to observe the bear with a strange fit of curiosity. Now that it had grown this large, how was it going to get out of the cave? Her answer came when the animal shuffled over to the far wall of the cave. It lifted its now table-sized paw and pressed it against the rocks. Hinata jolted as she heard the cave shifting and a beam of light illuminated the chamber. She quickly hid away as the bear stepped through the now exposed opening and disappeared into the blinding light.

Then as quickly as the doorway appeared, it vanished with a thud.

Hinata waited a full minute before stepping out from her hiding place, and inspecting the wall which the bear had disappeared into. The only thing unusual about the rocks was a strange crevice that looked suspiciously like a large bear’s paw. It didn’t take long for Hinata to put the clues together.

“I-It’s a secret passageway!”

Perhaps this was the entry into wherever lands the sloth was hiding. Maybe it led to more caves where the bears camped out underground. Hinata tried pressing her own hand up to the keyhole, and as expected nothing happened.

“It needs a b-bear to open it…” she deduced.

Some scurrying behind her made the Hyuga spin around to the relief that it was merely a cave rat. It squeaked at her and waddled over to the magical pool as it bubbled. Like the bear it dipped its head in and took a drink.

Hinata watched in amazement as the mouse began to swell to the size of a dog. Its long pale tail got sucked up into its butt and formed into a cute stubby tail, like a bear’s. Its ears also took on a smaller cub-like appearance. Lastly, its long front teeth disappeared and its snout shrink down slightly. In a matter of seconds, the rat now looked like a very, very small bear. Judging by the look on its face, it was just as surprised by this transformation as Hinata was.

“Groar!” it squeaked it her, before it stumbled back to the nearby walls, where it attempted to fit into the much-too-small mouse holes in the rock.

As Hinata watched the former rat’s pathetic attempts to escape, she had begun to wonder what exactly it was that she had just discovered. A pool that could make you grow and turn into a bear? Those things were supposed to be mere legend. One thing was for sure, though, there was something on the other side of the wall.

Hinata couldn’t simply break down the cave wall. If her hunch was correct, this was where the sloth had been hiding out. If she broke in violently, they would probably see it as an invasion and all peace talks would be off. She had to hide another way.

And that’s when her thoughts turned to the pool. It appeared to be some sort of ritual to enter, if observing the previous bear was any clue. And drinking this water would turn anything into a bear. Hinata gingerly lingered closer to the pool and…
1353322122212121.title: The Bear Pool

choices: Risk it and go to the sloth only with her bear hand.
Don't take chances, drink the vial.
13533221222121212.content:
Hinata thought it would be best to bide her time and think on what to do rather than jump right in. She knew very little about the water or the full range of its effects. All she knew was that it would turn those who drank from it into bears, though she had no idea how long it might last.

‘Maybe Sage Fukasaku might know something about this water,’ Hinata thought as she reached into her bag and took out a bottle. She had one on hand as part of her limited medical training in order to take any poison or dangerous materials for analysis.

Carefully, she took the vial out and uncorked it before bringing it back towards the water. As she dipped the vial in to gather water, her left hand made contact with the water.

Hinata felt a tingle at first before she noticed her hand was changing. Her nails grew sharper and thinner, growing more beast-like before her eyes. At first Hinata thought she was imagining it before the pads on her palm and fingers. She started to worry as her fingers and thumb became shorter. Gradually it started to become a paw, covered in light brown fur. Hinata gasped, but was careful to take a cloth and wipe off the remaining water.

Hinata grabbed the vial in her other hand and looked at the paw she possessed in place of her usual one.

She could move the fingers on it well enough, but it would in no way serve to create handsigns. At her wrist, her transformed paw stopped.

“Oh, dear…”

~

An hour later, Hinata found her teammates and allies reunited close outside the caves. The group was in high spirits, although they seemed to still be miffed at Naruto. Said blond was the first to notice her presence.

“Oh, Hinata. You’re okay!”

“Yes, and I made a discovery. A rather strange one, really…” Hinata then showed her transformed hand to them.

"Woah." Raz immediately took interest in his commander's disfigured hand. "Is it real?"

"Of course it's real, you dunderhead." Spades smacked the giant across the back of the head. "And its creepy, Commander. Can you fix it?"

Hinata flexed her left hand. "I-I haven't the slightest idea. There's no way I can do any jutsu like this though. O-Or, at least it will be difficult."

"I can relate," chuckled Naruto as he squeezed together his own replacement hand.

"I was hoping Fukasaku might have some information on this...Curse," Hinata produced a small vial. "T-This caused it. I found it after I escaped the bear in a nearby cave."

To save her from explaining her story twice, Naruto got to work summoning Fukasaku to the group. After an exchange of greetings, the old frog listened intently as Hinata conveyed all that she had observed just moments ago.

"Well, now. This is interesting, Naruto-boy," croaked the sage. "I haven't heard of anything like this since the olden days."

"Is it some sort of curse?" asked Raz.

"N-Now that I think about it," replied Hinata. “It looked like some sort of ritual.”

"You're both half-right. Naruto-boy, you remember your training on Mount Myoboku with the special oil few months back, yeah?”

Naruto’s face brightened up. “Oh, yeah! That stuff was weird and would have turned me into a frog statue if I wasn’t perfectly still.”

“Correct. I suspect whatever this water is it’s in the same vein as the oil on Mount Myoboku. Like how the oil advanced your training, perhaps this is a way for the bears to test the commitment of potential sages. It’s very in line with the old way of thinking amongst the summonable beasts. Prove your worth by becoming one of them and forsaking your old life.”

Hinata gulped. She was not looking forward to having a bear claw for a hand for the rest of her life. “D-Does that mean it is permanent?”

“Not necessarily, but I have no way of knowing. If you want those kinds of answers, you’re going to need to find the ones who created the water, the bears. Sounds like your mission just got a little more personal, my girl.”

Indeed it had. As interesting as a sensation the transform had been, this was no longer funny. This was serious. Hinata absentmindedly played with the pads on her palm and sighed.

‘W-What are our options for how to proceed?”

“Well,” croaked Fukasaku. “Considering your condition, I’d recommend going straight back to the bear’s lair. You can use your hand to your advantage and open whatever locking mechanism they have in place, from the sounds of things. The problem is your appearance. I’d wager they won’t be happy to see a bunch of humans have cheated their security system.”

“So, what you’re s-saying is…?”

“Drink the vial if you want them to treat you like one of their sloth,” the sage politely finished.

“No way!” cried out Naruto. “It sounds like we may not even get to change her back! It’s way too risky.”

“You all knew the risks when you signed up for this mission. Are you ninja or not?”

Fukasaku was right. All of them were aware of the code of ninja. They had a duty to complete their mission with utmost efficiency, no matter the cost. If her mission required that she sacrifice her own humanity and become a bear, Hinata would follow through. However, Naruto could be right. There might be a better alternative than having the commander of their squad transformed into an animal, perhaps indefinitely.

Oh, how Hinata detested the pains of leadership.
13533221222121212.title: The Pains of Leadership

choices: She sent Naruto and Spades back before going onwards
She insisted the bears let her friends stay.
135332212221212121.content:
“I-I don’t want to risk being stuck as a bear forever,” Hinata admitted to the group. “That might be my own shortcoming, but it feels rash to even consider it as our only option. W-We have a way in, we should use it.”

“I agree,” said Naruto. “It’s way too risky to go off with this on a hunch.”

While Hinata was grateful Naruto would support her decision, it undermined her authority somewhat to have her boyfriend attempt to take her side in a tough decision as the team leader.

“Suit yourself,” croaked Fukasaku. “The bears weren’t exactly known for their understanding. You’re going on their territory, after all. You should follow their rules as a guest, but it’s none of my business. Don’t end up dead, Naruto-boy.”

And with that, the frog disappeared in a puff of smoke, returning back to his home and leaving the rest of the team to ponder their future plans.

~

After spending the night camping and debating how to approach the sloth, Hinata and her group were on their way back to the cave by morning.

The group was uncomfortably quiet as they jumped from tree to tree. This was largely due in part to Hinata, who hadn’t said a word to anyone after they went over their plan of attack once they reached the caves.

It would be simple. Hinata would lead the way by opening the entrance like she had seen the bear do while Raz would stand guard at the entrance, making sure no one or nothing followed them in behind. With Naruto and Spades as her escort, Hinata would continue to lead on into whatever awaited them inside the lair. They promised to let her do all the talking and she had to force Naruto into vowing to leave her behind in case things got back. She was the one who was “marked” after all.

After a half an hour of traveling, they at last reached their destination.

Hinata could feel the familiar din of the cave, wind howling as it passed over the opening. “A-Alright, this is the place. Guys, you know what to do.”

“Right, Commander.”

Waiting behind her near the cave, Raz sat outside of the cave entrance while Hinata entered with Naruto and Spades. On the way in, she saw the cave was empty. The former rat had disappeared, leaving the cavern pool the only thing within aside from the stalagmites, stalactites and the secret wall.

Hinata approached the spot she had seen before and then her transformed hand. She felt nervous, but knew she had a job to do. Walking up to it and steeling herself, she placed her paw there and watched as the cavern’s back opened and led to a path. It was vast and great, and far off Hinata could see a light. She walked ahead, followed by Naruto a just as the cavern wall closed.

She walked ahead and went on for a fair distance until she came to the exit. Once she did she saw her surroundings and gasped. She was in awe of the beauty. It was a large clearing, nearby were a number of trees.

It looked like an idyllic forest, so different from the rest of the Land of Bears. Hinata couldn’t imagine how they would ever want to leave such a place.

She began to search for trails that would lead to the sloth she sought when she heard a voice.

“An attempt by humans to draw near? Something we haven’t seen in some time,” a deep, masculine voice said.

Hinata turned to look, but found no one in sight.

“Hey, who’s-“ Naruto began when he realized he was supposed to let Hinata do the talking. He fell silent and let her take over

“We don’t mean to intrude on your territory. I just wanted to talk to you about your sloth being out and loose. They’ve been causing a lot of disturbances for others.”

“That can be expected when they wake from centuries long hibernation,” another voice, this one female, stated. “The younger ones need a chance to explore and see the world.”

“I understand, it’s just that I-”

“You needn’t explain. We’ve expected you for a time. Ursala told us you might arrive soon.”

“Ursala? Who is she?”

“We’ll reveal it soon. For now walk through the path to the right. All will be explained when you reach the end. You must send the others back, though. They are unwelcome”

Hinata started to worry about the situation. She thought it was the sloth of bears who were talking to her, but she wasn’t quite fond of having to send her team away. She thought on what would be the best course of action before she made her decision.
135332212221212121.title: Risk it and go to the sloth only with her bear ...

1353322122212121211.content:
“Y-You guys go back,” ordered Hinata.

“What? Are you crazy, Hinata?” asked Naruto, clearly not thrilled with the thought of his girlfriend heading in alone. “You can’t do jutsu! What if this is a trap.”

“I doubt this is a t-trap, Naruto.” Hinata held her ground. “They sounded like they merely wanted to talk, else they could have f-forced me to comply. We came here on our own will as diplomats.”

“T-The commander is right,” Spades spoke up, looking around the forest with worried glances. “We should go and leave this to her.”

“She’s right, Naruto. Y-You should go. I’ll be fine,” added Hinata.

Behind them, the cavern wall opened up again as if on Hinata’s command. The cave almost beckoned them and Spades quickly stepped through. She turned to Naruto, expecting him to follow a superior officer’s orders, even if she was his significant other.

“Go on,” she repeated.

Naruto grunted angrily, not wanting to obey but knowing that a probable fight in his future would be waiting for him back in Konoha if he didn’t comply. Hinata had had a long talk with him before about what being under her command meant. Even if her orders went against her self-preservation, he was to follow them to the letter. Begrudgingly, Naruto stepped through the entrance and gave Hinata one last worried look before the rock slammed shut.

Hinata jumped slightly as the familiar female voice echoed across the trees around her. “Such a fortunate potential sage. She has a suitable mate, and the binder of the Nine Tails, no less.”

“Y-You knew?”

“Of course, we could sense his foul chakra miles away. Though I must admit, it had a far less sinister feeling since I last basked in it.”

Hinata struggled to maintain her composure as the nearby Cliffside moved. The bear’s sanctuary had been in a small valley tucked away between the mountains where no one could find it unless they flew overhead. Only now did Hinata realize that the large looming shapes overhead hadn’t all been the mountains themselves.

“Oh my…”

Staring down at her, big as any summons from a ninja master, was a massive bear, it was like she had encountered in the forest days earlier. It certainly wasn’t the same creature, Hinata could tell by its presence, but it was just as intimidating with its great size. It was everything Hinata could do to not flinch as it brought it nose right up to her face. This thing could swallow her whole if it wanted to.

“You are afraid,” it spoke after sniffing her. The bear’s inhalation had almost pulled her completely forward.

“Yes,” replied Hinata. She wasn’t about to lie.

“And honest. I can see why Ursala liked you. And after you helped her cub, it’s clear why she trusts you.”

“Y-You mean that bear in the forest earlier was this Ursala?”

But the bear in front of her ignored her question and continued her inspection of Hinata, prodding her gently with its nose. “Yes, yes. You will do nicely. Clever too. Not many would think to use only part of the holy waters to purify only their hand for entrance into the sacred grove. What do you think, Yanmir?”

Another rumble filled the valley as an even larger shadow was cast over Hinata. The scarred face of a bigger bear loomed over her, making Hinata feel even smaller by comparison. This one, however, had the distinctive male voice she had heard before.

"She seems very timid."

"Only because she has to see your ugly face, you old coot," said the female bear.

The bigger bear growled. "You're older than I am, Medve."

"U-Um," Hinata interrupted. "Excuse me, but what do you mean by 'I'll do?'"

"Don't you know?" asked the female bear. "You're here to become our first sage since our awakening. Why else would you be here?"

"B-Because your sloth have been rampaging in Konoha's lands."

"Konoha?"

"The village hidden in the leaves."

Both bears chuckled slightly. "How cute. The humans have expanded their territories. And just how important is this Konoha? Have the humans finally stopped feuding with each other as clans?"

It only now just registered with Hinata just how old these bears were. They truly had been born during the time of the Sage, before the villages had even been formed or the clans disbanded. Hinata had no idea where she could even begin to answer their questions.

"It's...C-Complicated."

"Hah," said Medve. "That describes human nature perfectly. But it's all the more reason we need you."

"You...Need me?"

"It has been centuries since we have awoken," continued Yanmir. "And now that we have returned, we need an advisor and friend in this new foreign world. The role of a sage will fulfill this. You will be our first sage and learn the ways of the bear."

"Y-You mean you want me to become a bear sage?"

"Correct," replied Medve. "By finding the way into our hallowed vale and impressing all three of us elders, you have proven your worth enough to at least attempt the training."

"B-But what about the problem with your sloth? Your kin are e-encroaching on our lands and hurting people. If you don't cease this, there will be w-war."

"You see? This is why we need you as our sage. The sloth moves on its own without respect towards any human. Even if we called them back, they would eventually begin to wander again. Only a sage would be able to manage them by rights of blood and bounding."

"S-So, in order to have peace, you need a sage?"

"Correct," the female bear repeated. "And right now, you are the only human with approval from all the elders."

"For the most part," huffed Yanmir. "There are many trials for you to overcome. You may not succeed."

"A-And if I refuse?"

"Considering we are the only ones with a cure for your hand, you should at least attempt the trials or you will never return to normal again."

With all that had happened, Hinata nearly forgot that her hand was still very much a bear's paw. She flexed it slightly, knowing full-well that that might be some cures for this curse, but considering the olive branch the bears were offering her it probably wasn't worth the risk. She couldn't do jutsu until she was back to normal, and the sloth wanted to make her an ambassador of sorts. It seemed like a win-win, but something didn't feel right.

It was only with slight hesitation that Hinata said. "V-Very well. I will accept the trials and attempt to become a bear sage."

"Wonderful," said Medve. "Now, where do we begin...?"
1353322122212121211.title: Bear Naked with Chicks

13533221222121212112.content:
“First question,” said Yanmir as he faced Hinata. “Have you always been that small?”

That was a rather brash question, even for an animal. “P-Pardon?”

“I said have you always been so small? With humans, I can never remember. I seem to recall you not getting much larger than you are now.”

“They do tend to be so tiny, don’t they?” said Medve.

“Quite. If you are to be our sage and command any respect amongst the sloth, you’re going to need confidence and the stature to match such a position. You being a meager human simply will not do.”

Hinata did not like the sound of that. “D-Does that mean…?”

“You need to become one of us,” finished the female bear. “It’s a sort of physical training, if you will.”

Even after finding the magical pond that turn her hand into part bear, Hinata was still not able or willing to comprehend actually becoming a full bear. She had heard from Naruto that the training to become a sage was some of the most intense and absurd exercises he had ever done, with him almost ending up as a frog at a few points. But this went beyond anything she could imagine the sloth to ask of her for the sake of peace.

“D-Do I have to? I mean, there’s got to be some other way to earn the sloth’s respect.”

Both bears looked at her in a very unimpressed way. It didn’t take long for Hinata to see why. Bumbling through the bushes of the valley came several very large bears, though not nearly as huge as Medve or Yanmir. They looked to be cubs, all of them around the size as the wood Hinata had saved in the forest. They playfully pawed at her feet, causing Hinata to immediately seize up at the sight of a bunch of animals the size of cars attempting to swipe her legs.

“Well, go on,” said Yanmir, cocking his head expectantly. “If you can’t earn the respect of mere children, you can’t hope to earn the esteem required to command the sloth.”

Hinata threw her hands up in surrender as the cubs licked at her face. “E-Enough! I get it!”

Medve gave a soft growl, causing all the cubs to cease their attacks on Hinata instantly. They stood at attention as Hinata cleaned herself off of their spittle.

“Reason is not the way of the bear,” spoke Yanmir. “Strength and power show true leadership amongst our ranks. You cannot hope to have either as you are now, therefore you must become one of us.”

“I understand,” repeated Hinata in a much calmer tone. She needed to keep her composure, whatever the bear’s opinions were on diplomacy. “I apologize, but y-you must understand how difficult it is to simply give up my humanity.”

“No, I don’t,” replied Yanmir, gruffly. “You humans are soft and weak. Why wouldn’t you want to be a bear?”

“I understand,” interrupted Medve, earning herself an angry growl from her male counterpart. “I apologize for my mate. He does not understand sentimentality. I know you have some doubts, my dear, but rest assured this is not a permanent process. You can return to normal…Given time.”

The female bear’s reassurance helped Hinata relaxed slightly. So long as what she was getting into wasn’t forever, she could be more comfortable with turning into a bear, as strange as the concept was. Hinata closed her eyes and sighed.

“A-Alright, I’ll do it.”

“At last,” muttered Yanmir. “Come.”

The mighty bear took large strides further into the forest as Hinata and Medve followed close behind. Eventually, the group came to a clearing where there was a large ursine-looking tree surrounded by many other cubs like the ones that had swarmed her earlier.

“T-They’re all children,” noted Hinata.

“Of course,” answered Medve. “This place is simply a nursery or the first step in the journey for the bears on our pilgrimage. We are here as protectors and teachers, helping those too young to live on their own or those on their first step to joining the sloth.”

“S-So, it’s the first step in their journey.”

“Correct. A perfect place for you to start.”

That explained why the bear that had chased her into the cave in the first place. Hinata’s thoughts were interrupted by Yanmir, who cleared his throat and sat next to the bear-shaped tree. He towered over it. With one massive paw, he pointed in the direction of the “mouth” of the sapling.

“Drink.”

He was motioning towards the strange yellow liquid that seemed to be dripping from the fangs of the tree statue. Upon closer inspection, Hinata saw that the substance appeared to be some sort of sap from the veins of the timber. Considering the pool of water at the entrance had transformed her hand, she could only imagine what this would do.

There was no turning back now though. Both giants were staring her down, expecting her to take a sip. Hinata took a few deep breaths.

“Here goes nothing…”

She held back her long hair and dipped her head into the running liquid. Surprisingly, the substance was sweet, like honey. When she had gotten a good mouthful of the sap, Hinata leaned back and swallowed. Then she waited.

Nothing happened.

“Um,” said Hinata, looking herself over for any signs of change. “I-Is this supposed to happen?”

“Yes,” said Medve. “To partake in the Nectar of the Mountain is to begin a long process of transformation which will occur over the course of one month.”

“One month!?”

“We do not wish to overwhelm our potential sage with a sudden transformation when the intention is to get you used to the idea of being a bear. A slow metamorphism into a bear over the course of one moon will be enough for you to get used to the changes done to your body.”

“It’s better than my idea,” said Yanmir. “I wanted to simply toss you into the pool. Less waiting.”

Hinata gulped. “I-I see…Well, what can I expect then?”

“Over the month?” asked Medve. “Well, the first changes will be small, maybe your teeth will sharpen or your ears may change shape. But by the end of the first week, you will notice a great increase in mass and height. The second week is when the fur starts growing in. Of course, the changes aren’t just physical later on, but I shall not spoil the surprise.”

Hinata felt a creeping dread spread over her. She had been prepared for an instant transformation, but this almost felt like torture. “W-What will happen after the full month?”

“You’ll see.” Medve seemed to be smiling. “I repeat. This is to teach you how to be a bear. There’s no better way to learn.”

“S-Should I stay in the grove to learn?” Hinata’s thoughts turned to Naruto and the others.

“That won’t be necessary. You should say goodbye to your family and mate while you can. You’re going to be busy the next few months learning our ways. No human contact will be allowed during that session.”

Hinata nodded. “W-Well, thanks…I guess. So, I’ll s-see you both in…?”

“A month,” Medve politely finished. “Ta-ta, my dear. I never did learn your name.”

“H-Hinata. Hinata Hyuga.”

“See you in a month, Hinata.”

Yanmir merely grunted a farewell.

~

Later that day...

135332212221212121121.content:
“A-And that’s my report, Lord Hokage.”

Kakashi leaned far back into his chair, facial expressions hidden by both his mask and the mountain of paperwork at his desk. He stared hard into the eyes of both Hinata and her team, as they stood sheepishly in the back of the room. The mission had ended quicker than any of them had expected, with Raz even complaining that they hadn’t really even done anything.

“Well, that’s quite the tale, Hinata. And how do you feel, exactly? Are you alright?”

Truthfully, the journey back to Konoha had left Hinata in a sort of daze. She wasn’t exactly coming to terms with her supposed crash course transforming into a bear, it was all fuzzy to her. Even the Hokage’s words seemed distant and foreign as she stumbled in place, lost in thought.

“Y-Yes, I’m fine. Please, don’t worry about me.”

“Then you’re sure this is what you want? It sounds like a very heavy price to pay for becoming the new bear sage. If you’re unsure, it might not be too late to go to them and ask to reverse the process.”

Hinata flexed her bear claw a little, uncomfortably. “No, really, I’m fine. This is the best course of action for the v-village.”

Hinata noticed that Kakashi wasn’t the only one giving her a worried stare. Everyone in the room, especially Naruto and her teammates, was staring at her with a mixture of pity and concern. Perhaps they felt she was taking this news too well, but Hinata truly didn’t feel anything about it. The panic of becoming a bear was nothing more than a distant memory or a feeling, lodged firmly in the back of her mind.

“…Very well,” continued Kakashi, folding his hands and sighing. “Seeing as you’re so determined, I won’t stop you and will leave this assignment in your capable hands. As you…Progress, I will alert the rest of the village not to be alarmed by your presence. During that time and until you meet with the sloth again, your team will act as your personal guard. They will protect you from any threats while you remain indisposed.”

“Yes, Lord Hokage,” everyone but Naruto said in unison. The blond ninja instead glared bitterly at his former master.

“Good. Dismissed.”

~

Hinata and her team stepped out of the tower just as the sun was beginning to set on the horizon. It had been a long day.

As they stepped away from the doors, Naruto turned to Raz and handed him a coin.

“Raz, go with Spades and buy some ramen. You guys deserve a little treat.”

“With all due respect, Mister Naruto, I think we were going to—”

“I said,” interrupted Naruto with a more angry tone of voice. “Go take Spades and get some ramen, do you understand?”

Hinata could practically see the Nine Tailed Fox’s aura flare up, intimidating both her cadets into almost fleeing the scene instantly. Naruto sighed as they jumped onto the rooftops and into the night life of Konoha, far out of sight from him and his girlfriend. Hinata pretended to be disinterested, though even if she wasn’t listening, she could tell a fight was coming on.

“Why did you do it?” asked Naruto.

“Because it was the only way I could earn the trust of the bears. You know that they need to have a sage to learn under them. Besides that, they’ve been isolated from the ninja world for a very long time,” Hinata explained. “What if they decided they didn’t like how humans did things or if some rogue ninja was their first impression of humans and somehow managed to become their sage? I couldn’t let that happen.”

“I know, but it’s dangerous. You can’t put yourself at risk like that,” Naruto said. “You’ve already done it too many times to count. Back when you and Neji were young, against Pain, during the war…Each of those times you put your life on the line. What happens if you do it again and you don’t come back?”

“Then it will be because of what I chose. From the moment I became a ninja, I put my life at risk and knew the consequences. I’m willing to die in order to protect whatever I value, just like you.” Hinata then placed out her transformed pawn and reached out for Naruto’s hand. The blond was confused for a second, but took it before Hinata resumed. “Do you remember your nindo?”

“Yeah. It was to never back down or run from a challenge.”

“If this is a ninja way you believe in, then why would you ask me to do the opposite of it? I don’t want to run, so don’t ask me to avoid doing something you would for the sake of others.”

Naruto fell silent and his expression was somewhat disappointed. He folded his arms and looked down before opening his eyes.

“Yeah…I guess you’re right,” Naruto said. “I just don’t want to lose you is all.”

“Just have faith in my skill and resolve, then you’ll never have to worry again.” Hinata took her bearlike paw away from him. “Alright?”

“Yes…Commander Hyuga.”

“Uh, you can still call me Hinata, Naruto.” Hinata said to him. She could tell Naruto was trying to be more respectful, but the way he said Commander seemed hard for him.

“Phew, thanks. So are you going to rest?”

“No, I’m going to go see the sloth of Bears again once I finish resting and have time to prepare. I will send a letter for you, Raz and Spades to join me later on once I’ve fully gained their trust..”

“Gotcha. Be safe, Hinata.”

The lavender eyed young woman nodded. Even without jutsu, she was determined to make her way and learn as much as she could from the bears.

-

A few days later Hinata was back with the sloth of bears. During this time Hinata found herself having a hard time adjusting to her new surroundings. While it was training ground for cubs and a place with virtually no conflict or danger she couldn't’ help but worry about her mission.

Hinata knew that the task set before her was an important one, but she secretly feared failing. Hinata had grown quite a bit since her days as a genin. She remembered when she was younger and meek, too afraid to do much at all.

Since then she had faced her fears, become a chunin, faced many threats in the ninja war and grown to become a powerful ninja in her own right. Now wasn’t the time to let doubt take hold. This was the time for her to move forward and do what she could for the village. She believed what she had told Naruto, and more importantly she believed in herself.

‘Just remember your nindo,’ Hinata reminded herself. She decided it would be best to get the lay of the land and better understand the place where she was. She saw several young cubs at play. Either climbing trees or playing with eachother. They seemed so energetic and curious that it reminded Hinata somewhat of her academy days. Other children were as rambunctious as the young cubs were, even if the young bears were about the size of small buildings.

As Hinata walked, she began to feel strange. She couldn’t quite place it, but something felt somewhat different. Nonetheless, she decided to go towards a nearby river and wash her face. Once there, she looked at her reflection. Nothing there was different and her body seemed to be the same as well. Hinata chalked it up as her nerves and merely washed her face.

After a minute, she was completely washed and felt much more alert. That was when she looked at her reflection and noticed something odd about her teeth. One of them seemed to be looking sharper.

Taking her index finger, Hinata poked her tooth and found it was more sharp, as were a few others in her mouth. She hadn’t expected her teeth to change first.

Hinata smiled at her reflection and found herself chuckling.

“Finding your first changes appealing?” asked a female voice. Hinata gasped when she realized it was Medve.

“Oh, Medve. I was just surprised by my new teeth.”

“That is only natural. Those fangs are rather different from your human ones. Still, they should prove useful.”

“I’m sure they will.” Hinata gave a gentle smile. “So, what brings you out here?”

“I merely came to have a morsel or two,” Medve said as she pointed to the river. “The fish should be swimming about.”

“Really?”

“Yes. Would you like to see me try?”

Hinata nodded, seeing it as a good chance to learn. She watched as Medve started to paw at the fish, trying to catch them. Hinata looked at her own paw and wondered if she would be able to do the same someday. It was something she resolved to do well while she was there.

Something about Medve felt naturally motherly. No doubt it was the reason she was chosen to look over the place. While she had a moment alone with her, Hinata decided to…
